Title.evidence: Biventricular Pacing After Cardiac Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomised to either continuous biventricular pacing (n = 16) or standard of care (n = 18).

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients undergoing cardiac surgery, eligible based on risk of left ventricular dysfunction. The study was conducted in a cardiac surgery unit.

Intervention.evidence: compare biventricular pacing with atrial pacing

Objective.evidence: The objective was to compare biventricular pacing with atrial pacing in terms of hemodynamic outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was hemodynamic improvement, measured by cardiac output and vasoactive-inotropic score, over the first 24 hours post-bypass.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 34 patients were randomised and analysed.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 34 patients were randomised and analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 12 to 24 hours post-bypass, intrinsic heart rate was lower in the paced group (76.5 ± 17.5 vs 91.7 ± 13.0 beats per minute; P = .040). Cardiac output increased in the paced group (4.4 ± 1.2 vs 3.6 ± 1.9 L/min; P = .054).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
